title: Job Training Fee Scam
context: You applied for remote customer service jobs online. Someone contacts you about a position with great pay and flexible hours.

steps.text: Congratulations! You've been selected for our remote customer service position - $25/hour, flexible schedule. We just need you to complete our training program first. There's a $150 training fee, but you'll earn it back in your first week.
They send professional-looking documents and say the training fee covers 'equipment and certification.' They want payment before you can start. What's your response?

choices.text: Pay the training fee to secure the job
Ask them to deduct it from your first paycheck instead
Research the company independently before paying

steps.text: Employment scam using fake authority and foot-in-the-door technique! Legitimate employers never charge training fees - they pay you to train.
steps.explanation: Scammers pose as legitimate companies and use small initial requests (training fees) to hook victims. Real jobs pay you, not the other way around.

items.question: What should you never have to pay for when starting a legitimate job?
How can you verify if a job offer is legitimate?
